title: Basic Router Configuration
description: Initial settings, interface configuration, and default gateway setup

glance.label: Verification commands
glance.detail: show ip/ipv6 interface brief, route, etc.

blocks.content: Before a router can forward packets, it must be configured with basic settings. These seven tasks should be completed in order when configuring initial settings on any Cisco router.

steps.description: Configure the device name ‚Äî replaces the default generic prompt with something meaningful.
Secure privileged EXEC mode ‚Äî this is the most important mode to lock down as it provides complete access to the device.
Secure user EXEC mode ‚Äî protects access via the console cable.

steps.command:
line vty 0 4
password cisco
login
transport input ssh telnet
steps.description: Secure remote Telnet/SSH access ‚Äî locks down virtual terminal lines for remote connections.
Encrypt all plaintext passwords in the config file ‚Äî prevents casual viewing of passwords.
Provide legal notification ‚Äî warns unauthorised users that access is prohibited.
Save the configuration to NVRAM ‚Äî without this step, all changes are lost on reboot.

blocks.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Critical Reminder
blocks.content: If the router loses power before you save the config, all settings are lost. Always run copy running-config startup-config after making changes.

blocks.label: Privileged EXEC Mode
blocks.content: The mode that provides complete access to the device and its configuration. Secured with the enable secret command, which uses MD5 encryption. This is the most important mode to protect.

Routers are not reachable by end devices until interfaces are configured and activated. The Cisco ISR 4321 router has two Gigabit Ethernet interfaces: GigabitEthernet 0/0/0 (G0/0/0) and GigabitEthernet 0/0/1 (G0/0/1). Configuring a router interface is similar to configuring a switch SVI.

blocks.code:
Router(config)# interface gigabitEthernet 0/0/0
Router(config-if)# description Link to LAN
Router(config-if)# ip address 192.168.10.1 255.255.255.0
Router(config-if)# ipv6 address 2001:db8:acad:10::1/64
Router(config-if)# no shutdown

items: The description command is optional but highly recommended ‚Äî it helps with troubleshooting by documenting what connects to each interface (max 240 characters).
IPv4 and IPv6 addresses can be configured on the same interface simultaneously ‚Äî dual-stack operation.
The no shutdown command activates the interface ‚Äî it's like powering it on. Interfaces are administratively down by default.
When enabled, you should see informational messages confirming the link is up: %LINK-3-UPDOWN and %LINEPROTO-5-UPDOWN.
On inter-router connections (no switch between them), both interfaces must be configured and enabled for the link to come up.

blocks.title: üí° Interface Naming
blocks.content: Interface names follow the pattern type slot/module/port. For example, GigabitEthernet 0/0/0 means: GigabitEthernet type, slot 0, module 0, port 0. Shorter form: G0/0/0.
After configuring interfaces, use verification commands to confirm everything is working. The most useful commands display interface status, IP addresses, and routing tables.

rows: All interfaces with IPv4 addresses and status. Configured and connected interfaces show Status: up and Protocol: up. Anything else indicates a problem with config or cabling.
All interfaces with IPv6 addresses and status. Shows link-local and global unicast addresses. Uses [up/up] notation for operational interfaces.
The IPv4 routing table stored in RAM. Shows all known routes and how packets will be forwarded.
The IPv6 routing table stored in RAM. Essential for verifying IPv6 connectivity.
Detailed statistics for all interfaces. Shows only IPv4 addressing info, not IPv6.
Detailed IPv4 statistics for all interfaces on the router.
Detailed IPv6 statistics for all interfaces on the router.

blocks.title: ‚ö° Quick Status Check
blocks.content: For a fast overview, always start with show ip interface brief and show ipv6 interface brief. Both interfaces should show up/up. If you see administratively down, the interface needs no shutdown. If you see down/down, check the cable.

blocks.label: Default Gateway
blocks.content: The router interface address on the local network that hosts use to reach devices on other networks. The default gateway is only used when a host wants to send a packet to a device outside its own subnet. The host's IP address and the default gateway address must be in the same network.

For an end device to communicate beyond its local network, it must be configured with the correct IP address, subnet mask, and default gateway address. When a host sends a packet to a local destination (same subnet), it uses ARP and sends directly. When sending to a remote destination (different subnet), it forwards the packet to its default gateway.

items.title: Local Traffic
items.description: PC1 sending to PC2 (both on 192.168.10.0/24). Default gateway is NOT used. PC1 addresses the packet with PC2's IP and forwards directly through the switch.

items.title: Remote Traffic
items.description: PC1 sending to PC3 (different subnet). Default gateway IS used. PC1 addresses the packet with PC3's IP but forwards to its default gateway (R1 G0/0/0). The router then routes it to the destination.

blocks.content: A Layer 2 switch doesn't need an IP address to function ‚Äî it switches frames based on MAC addresses. However, to remotely manage a switch (SSH, Telnet, web interface), it needs an SVI (Switch Virtual Interface) with an IP address AND a default gateway configured.

blocks.code:
Switch(config)# interface vlan 1
Switch(config-if)# ip address 192.168.10.50 255.255.255.0
Switch(config-if)# no shutdown
Switch(config-if)# exit
Switch(config)# ip default-gateway 192.168.10.1

items: The ip default-gateway command is a global configuration command ‚Äî not an interface command.
The default gateway IP must be the router interface address on the same network as the switch SVI.
Without a default gateway, the switch can't reply to management traffic from remote networks ‚Äî SSH from another subnet won't work.
For IPv6, switches automatically learn the default gateway from ICMPv6 Router Advertisement messages ‚Äî no manual configuration needed.

blocks.title: üí° Why Switches Need Default Gateways
blocks.content: Example: Admin on 192.168.11.0/24 tries to SSH to switch on 192.168.10.0/24. The SSH request reaches the switch via the router. The switch needs to send its reply BACK through the router ‚Äî that's where the default gateway comes in. Without it configured, the switch can receive but can't reply to remote connections.

left.label: Host Default Gateway
left.content: Configured in the operating system's network settings (Windows, Mac, Linux). Used by the host to reach any remote network. Must match the router interface IP on the local LAN.

right.label: Switch Default Gateway
right.content: Configured with ip default-gateway command in global config mode. Used only for management traffic replies. Not needed for normal switching operation ‚Äî only for remote admin access.

blocks.note: Both must point to the router interface IP on their local network segment.

blocks.content: Following these best practices ensures routers are configured securely and consistently, making troubleshooting easier and reducing security risks.

items.title: Use Descriptive Hostnames
items.description: Choose meaningful names that identify location or function: R1-HQ-CORE, R2-BRANCH-EDGE. Makes managing large networks much easier.

items.title: Document with Descriptions
items.description: Add descriptions to every interface: 'Link to ISP', 'LAN Segment A', 'Connection to R2 G0/0/1'. Essential for troubleshooting months later.

items.title: Always Save Configs
items.description: Never skip copy running-config startup-config. Power loss means you lose everything otherwise. Make it automatic habit after every change.

items.title: Use Strong Passwords
items.description: Never use default or simple passwords like 'cisco' or 'password'. Use enable secret (encrypted) instead of enable password (plaintext).

items.title: Verify After Config
items.description: Always run show commands to verify your configuration worked. Don't assume ‚Äî check the interface status and routing table.

items.title: Enable Password Encryption
items.description: Run service password-encryption to prevent casual password viewing in the config. Not super strong encryption, but better than plaintext.

blocks.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Common Mistakes
blocks.content: Forgetting no shutdown is the #1 beginner mistake ‚Äî interfaces are admin down by default. #2 is forgetting to save the config. #3 is wrong subnet mask causing reachability issues. Always verify with show ip interface brief!
